_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Recommendation items have been budgeted, projected completion December 31, 2023.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ty.

Energy Transfer Spindletop facility has developed programs to comply with all environmental, health, and safety laws. Energy Transfer Spindletop facility takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases.  Our risk management program addresses each of the essential features of successful accident prevention programs, including:
1.	Process Safety Information
2.	Process Hazard Analysis
3.	Operating Procedures
4.	Training
5.	Management of Change
6.	Pre-Startup Safety Review
7.	Compliance Audits
8.	Incident Investigation
9.	Employee Participation
10.	Hot Work Permits
11.	Contractor Safety
12. 	LOTO

Five-Year Accident History
We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. In the past five years we have had no incidents involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule that meet the reporting requirements set forth in the program.

Emergency Response Program
Energy Transfer Spindletop facility is a member of the Jefferson County LEPC & Mutual Aid.  The facility emergency response plan which details procedures for accidental releases and includes notification of the Jefferson County LEPC & Mutual Aid as well as the Energy Transfer Nederland Fire Brigade.  We maintain an open door policy with local emergency response organizations to help ensure maximum understanding and cooperation during an emergency.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The Energy Transfer Spindletop facility personnel continually strive to improve all aspects of our safety programs to protect our workers and the public. The following is a list of ongoing improvements that we are implementing at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:
a.	Safety upgrades on the Ethylene Dehydration system.
b.	Flare system upgrade project. 
c.	Creating a Mechanical Integrity program upon completion of the above-mentioned projects.

Accident Prevention and Response Policies
Energy Transfer Spindletop facility, in Beaumont, Texas is an Ethylene Dehydration and storage facility.  The facility utilizes certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary on-site human exposure and to minimize the potential for any offsite exposure.  

These safety precautions include:
1.	Effectively managing our process operations;
2.	Investing in the latest process safety technologies, training, and retraining our personnel;
3.	Reviewing our processes for hazards on a continuous basis;
4.	Ensuring safety is considered in process design, installation, operations, and maintenance.

The facility maintains a policy to be a good business partner; a safe and conscientious neighbor; and to operate in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Energy Transfer Spindletop facility RMP regulated flammable substances identified at the facility is Ethylene (C2 H4). For identifying the maximum release quantity for use in determining potential off-site impacts, it is assumed that the entire contents of the vessel or the system are released to the atmosphere, forming a vapor cloud. Using the criteria outlined in the ARP rule and the calculations provided by RMP*Comp it was determined that Ethylene (C2 H4) present in the Vertical Molecular Sieve Adsorber, V-6210 represents the facilitys worst-case scenario for flammables. Calculations for all three vessels containing regulated substances were performed to determine end points and are provided in Scenario Modeling.

The General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Plant Supervisor has overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.
